Cerita Orang yang Nyaris Bunuh Diri di Hutan Aokigahara
03 Nov 2019, 13:40 by Afif Farhan


Hutan Aokigahara di kaki Gunung Fuji (Thinkstock)

Tokyo - Hutan Aokigahara disebut sebagai tempat terseram di dunia, sebagai hutan bunuh diri. Ini cerita salah satu orang yang nyaris mengakhiri hidup di sana.Aokigahara terletak di bagian barat laut Gunung Fuji, sekitar 100 kilometer sebelah barat Tokyo, Jepang. Dengan luas 30 kilometer persegi, hutan tersebut cukup subur akibat curahan lahar yang berasal dari Gunung Fuji ketika gunung tersebut meletus tahun 864.BACA JUGA: Mengapa Jepang Disebut 'Negeri Matahari Terbit'?Silakan cari di internet tentang tempat-tempat terseram di dunia, pasti Aokigahara masuk dalam daftarnya. Tak ayal, inilah lokasi bunuh diri paling terkenal dari Jepang.Menurut laporan pemerintah Jepang, rata-rata 100 orang melakukan bunuh diri di hutan Aokigahara tiap tahunnya!


Suasana di hutan Aokigahara (Carl Court/Getty Images)

Mengapa banyak orang yang bunuh diri di hutan Aokigahara? Sebab, hutan ini begitu lebat dan sekali masuk sulit mencari jalan pulang. Serta sejak tahun 1960-an, sudah banyak orang yang bunuh diri di sana."Banyak orang telah bunuh diri di Aokigahara, dengan begitu Anda tidak akan mati sendirian. Itu sebabnya, orang-orang mau bunuh diri di sana karena bagaikan ada teman atau orang-orang lain yang mendukungnya," profesor antropologi dari Jepang, Karen Nakamura.Usut punya usut, Jepang masuk dalam datar negara maju dengan angka bunuh diri tertinggi. Menurut laporan World Health Organization (WHO), ada 15 kasus bunuh diri per 100.000 populasi yang dipecah menjadi 9 untuk wanita dan 21 untuk pria.BACA JUGA: Jepang dan Filosofi 'Satu Hal Pada Satu Waktu'CNN pernah mewawancarai Taro, salah seorang pria asal Tokyo. Tahun 2009, Taro pernah nyaris melakukan bunuh diri di Aokigahara."Saya dipecat dari pekerjaan, saya sudah tidak punya keinginan untuk hidup. Saya mau mati," katanya membuka perbincangan.Taro kala itu bekerja di perusahaan manufaktur di Tokyo. Perekonomiannya pun terancam, sehingga dia memilih untuk bunuh diri dan pergi ke Aokigahara.


(Carl Court/Getty Images)

"Saya mulai memotong pergelangan tangan saya," ujarnya.Namun yang terjadi, luka-luka di pergelangan tangannya ternyata tidak fatal. Sehingga, Taro pingsan.Dia pun kemudian tidak bisa banyak bergerak dan dehidrasi karena tidak membawa perbekalan. Berhari-hari, dia kelaparan dan di situlah benar-benar mendekati kematian."Saya akhirnya ditemukan dan diselamatkan oleh orang-orang, para petugas di sana," terangnya.Taro pun kembali melanjutkan hidup. Aksi nyaris bunuh dirinya, tentu menjadi titik balik yang mengembalikan semangat hidupnya.BACA JUGA: Menguak Aokigahara, Hutan Bunuh Diri di JepangUntuk mencegah potensi bunuh diri, pemerintah Jepang mengerahkan petugas patroli dan memasang kamera pengawas. Pemilik toko-toko di sekitar hutan juga bersedia sebagai relawan untuk mencegah bunuh diri. Pemilik sebuah kedai kopi di pintu masuk hutan, misalnya, mengklaim kepada surat kabar Japan Times bahwa dia telah menggagalkan 160 aksi bunuh diri selama 30 tahun dengan mengamati pengunjung yang datang sendirian.Di beberapa tempat ada penanda dan peringatan berisi informasi konseling anti-bunuh diri. Sejumlah penanda bahkan berisi imbauan kepada pengunjung untuk 'merenungkan anugerah kehidupan sekaligus rasa sakit yang Anda timbulkan untuk keluarga Anda'.


(aokigaharaforest.com)

Dengan pepohonan lebat dan hampir tidak ada binatang liar, Aokigahara merupakan tempat sunyi dan mencekam yang dipenuhi bebatuan dengan formasi janggal.Kabarnya, cerita mistis di sana adalah orang-orang yang mau bunuh diri seolah dipanggil oleh arwah-arwah yang sudah bunuh diri sebelumnya. Stories of Nearly Suicide Person in Aokigahara Forest
03 Nov 2019, 13:40 by Afif Farhan


Aokigahara Forest at the foot of Mount Fuji (Thinkstock)

Tokyo - Aokigahara Forest is said to be the scariest place in the world, as a forest of suicide. This is the story of one person who almost ended his life there. Okigahara is located in the northwestern part of Mount Fuji, about 100 kilometers west of Tokyo, Japan. With an area of 30 square kilometers, the forest is quite fertile due to the outpouring of lava that came from Mount Fuji when the mountain erupted in 864. READ ALSO: Why is Japan Called the Land of the Rising Sun? Aokigahara entered the list. No doubt, this is the most famous location of suicide in Japan. According to Japanese government reports, an average of 100 people commit suicide in the Aokigahara forest each year!


The atmosphere in the Aokigahara forest (Carl Court / Getty Images)

Why do so many people commit suicide in the Aokigahara forest? Because, this forest is so dense and once entered it is difficult to find a way home. And since the 1960s, many people have killed themselves there. "Many people have killed themselves in Aokigahara, so you will not die alone. That is why, people want to kill themselves there because it's like there are friends or people other people who support him, "professor of anthropology from Japan, Karen Nakamura. North Korea has a caliber, Japan entered the flat developed countries with the highest suicide rates. According to a World Health Organization (WHO) report, there were 15 suicides per 100,000 population divided into 9 for women and 21 for men. READ ALSO: Japan and the Philosophy 'One Thing at a Time' CNN has interviewed Taro, one of the men from Tokyo. In 2009, Taro almost committed suicide in Aokigahara. "I was fired from my job, I have no desire to live. I want to die," he said, opening the conversation. Taro was working at a manufacturing company in Tokyo. His economy was threatened, so he chose to commit suicide and went to Aokigahara.


(Carl Court / Getty Images)

"I started to cut my wrist," he said. But what happened, the injuries on his wrist were not fatal. Thus, Taro passed out. He then could not move much and was dehydrated because he did not bring supplies. For days, he was starving and it was there that he was really near death. "I was finally found and rescued by people, the officers there," he explained. Taro went back to life. The act of nearly killing himself would certainly be a turning point that restored his zest for life. READ ALSO: Revealing Aokigahara, Suicide Forest in Japan To prevent potential suicide, the Japanese government mobilized patrol officers and installed surveillance cameras. Shop owners around the forest are also willing to volunteer to prevent suicide. The owner of a coffee shop at the forest entrance, for example, claimed to the Japan Times newspaper that he had foiled 160 suicides over 30 years by observing visitors who came alone. In some places there were markers and warnings containing information on anti-suicide counseling. Some markers even contain an appeal to visitors to 'contemplate the gifts of life as well as the pain you are causing for your family'.


(aokigaharaforest.com)

With dense trees and almost no wild animals, Aokigahara is a quiet and gripping place filled with rocks with strange formations. Reportedly, mystical stories there are people who want to commit suicide as if summoned by spirits who had killed themselves before. Believe it or not!
